page_analysis.text_content:
Contextual garage placement
Contextual garage placement applies if, and only if, there is a predominant neighborhood pattern.
How to determine if contextual garage placement applies (using Fig 32 below as an example)
Note:
• If block is more than 600' long, consider only lots with in 600' or the 10 lots closest to the subject lot
• If subject lot is a corner lot, consider the pattern on the street that the subject garage faces
Exclude the following types of lots:
• Flag lot (C)
• Multi-family use of 3+ units (G)
• Corner lots (A & H)
The remaining lots including the subject lot, contribute to the determination.
Note:
• If block more than 600' long,
consider only lots within 600' or
10 closest lots.
• If subject lot is a corner lot, con-
sider the pattern on the street that
the garage faces
Divide the remaining lots, including
the subject lot, into two categories:
1. Front-half pattern lots
• lots with garage in front half of
the lot (F)
2. Rear-half pattern lots
• lots with garage in the rear half
of the lot (B & D) and
• lots with no garage (E) (counts
as a rear-pattern lot)
Determine which pattern category is
predominant i.e., into which catego-
ry more than half of the lots fall.
Front half
Rear half
The contextual-garage-
placement regulation DOES
apply. Projects on this block
must place the garage in the
rear half of the lot.
Fig 32 Example of a block on which the contextual garage placement regulation applies

visual_elements.description: A flowchart illustrating the process of determining contextual garage placement. It starts with 'Exclude the following types of lots' and 'The remaining lots including the subject lot, contribute to the determination.' leading to 'Divide the remaining lots, including the subject lot, into two categories: 1. Front-half pattern lots' and '2. Rear-half pattern lots'. These then lead to 'Determine which pattern category is predominant i.e., into which category more than half of the lots fall.' which branches into 'Front half' and 'Rear half'. The 'Rear half' path leads to a box stating 'The contextual-garage-placement regulation DOES apply. Projects on this block must place the garage in the rear half of the lot.'

Figure 32: An example block layout showing several lots (A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H) with houses and garages, illustrating different garage placements. Lot A is a corner lot with a house and garage, crossed out. Lot B has a house and a garage at the rear. Lot C is a flag lot with a house and garage, crossed out. Lot D has a house and a garage at the rear. Lot E has a house and no garage. Lot F is labeled 'Subject House' with a garage at the front. Lot G is a multi-family use lot with multiple garages, crossed out. Lot H is a corner lot with a house and garage, crossed out. The street is indicated at the bottom of the lots.

technical_specifications.parameter: Number of closest lots for consideration

additional_notes: Page number '37' is present at the bottom right corner.
